questions.text: A lady on OCP presents with white vaginal discharge that presents with no itching or foul smell. It stains her underwear yellow in colour and on examination of the discharge normal lactobacilli were presents and pH was acidic. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lack of itching or foul smell with acidic pH and presence of normal lactobacilli points towards normal vaginal discharge.

NORMAL PHYSIOLOGICAL DISCHARGE:

  • Vaginal squamous cells and cervical columnar cells in fluid medium
  • Clear to cloudy colour
  • Nonhomogenous
  • Highly viscous or sticky
  • No itching, vaginal burning, or malodor
  • Increase at the time of ovulation, during pregnancy, following menstruation
  • Normal endogenous microflora(lactobacilli)
  • pH acidic

Options A,B,C: Refer to the table:

choices.text: Weight loss + metformin+ ovulation induction with clomiphene
Weight loss + metformin + ovulation induction with urinary gonadotropins
Weight loss + folic acid, try for spontaneous induction, if fails move to ovulation induction

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with history of infertility for 6 years has BMI of 30 kg/m2 and excessive facial hair growth. Next step in management?
questions.solution:
Main treatment for PCOS is weight loss and lifestyle modification. It is required in all patients.

Treatment approach for PCOS:

  • Firstly, go for lifestyle modification like exercise and diet modification for weight loss
  • If lifestyle modification doesn’t work, next go for ovulation induction using : Letrozole or Clomiphene citrate(Option A)
  • If still not responding, go for ovulation induction using urinary gonadotrophins(Option B)
  • Metformin used in cases of insulin resistance and Acanthosis nigricans

Option D: Finasteride is an antiandrogen agent and if given can cause adverse effects in a male fetus and hence avoided.

Treatment for infertility in PCOS:

  • Letrozole should be considered as a first line agent for ovulation induction in women with PCOS and in those with resistance to clomiphene.
  • Treatment with insulin sensitizing agents has been used to increase ovulation rates.
  • Higher live birth rates seen in treatment with clomiphene + metformin than only clomiphene or metformin.

questions.text: Most common cause of puberty menorrhagia is?
questions.solution:
Puberty menorrhagia refers to excessive menstrual bleeding during adolescence, specifically around the time of puberty. It is characterized by heavy or prolonged menstrual periods, often lasting more than 7 days or involving the loss of more than 80 mL of blood per cycle. This condition is common in the early years after menarche (the onset of menstruation) due to the immaturity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis, which leads to anovulatory cycles (cycles without ovulation).

Causes:

  • Hormonal imbalances, particularly related to anovulatory cycles(the most common cause)
  • Coagulation disorders like von Willebrand disease
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Pelvic pathology such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) (though less common in early adolescence)

Symptoms:

  • Heavy menstrual bleeding
  • Irregular cycles
  • Fatigue, dizziness, or anemia from blood loss

Management:

  • Hormonal therapy (such as oral contraceptives) to regulate cycles
  • Iron supplementation for anemia
  • Evaluation for underlying disorders like coagulation issues or thyroid problems

Reference: www.researchgate.net

choices.text: Macrophage which have phagocytosed Doderlein bacilli

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to Gynaecology OPD with grey-white vaginal discharge and on gram stain of the discharge, clue cells are seen. What are these clue cells?
questions.solution:
This patient has BACTERIAL VAGINOSIS

  • It is polymicrobial infection resulting in alteration in normal microbial flora
  • Organisms implicated are:
  • Gardnerella vaginalis
  • Mycoplasma hominis
  • Ureaplasma
  • Pepstreptococcus
  • Mobiluncus curtisii
  • AMSEL'S CRITERIA: For diagnosis
  • a fishy vaginal odor with vaginal discharge
  • pH >4.5
  • microscopy: clue cell increases, leukocytes are absent.
  • Addition of KOH to vaginal secretion releases fishy, amine like odor (WHIFF TEST)

Other clinical features:

  • No pruritus, dysuria and dyspareunia
  • Off white colour discharge

Investigation of choice: Saline microscopy showing Clue cells

Fig. Clue cells in Bacterial vaginosis

CLUE CELLS: these are epithelial cells on whose cytoplasmic membrane bacteria are adhered.

TREATMENT: Metronidazole 500 mg BD * 7 days is drug of choice.

Treatment of male partner is not recommended.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is not given in endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Endometriosis is an estrogen dependent condition and giving Estrogen might worsen the condition

Medical treatment for endometriosis includes:

  • NSAIDs
  • COC pills
  • Progesterone: POP, DMPA, implanon, mirena, Dienogest
  • GnRH agonist: leuprolide,nafarelin,goserelin
  • GnRH antagonists: elagolix, relugolix
  • Danazol, gestrinone
  • Aromatase inhibitors: anastrazole, letrozole
  • SPRM: ulipristal, mifepristone
  • SERM: bazedoxifene
  • Cabergoline

Surgical management:

  • Adhesiolysis
  • Fulguration of implants using bipolar cautery
  • Excision of implants
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation(LUNA)
  • Presacral neurectomy
  • TAH+BSO(if family is complete)

questions.text: SRY gene located at
questions.solution:
Male sexual differentiation is an active process requiring the presence of the SRY GENE which is located on Short aRm of Y chromosome.

Clinically, gender is not apparent until about 12 week of embryonic life and depends on the elaboration of testes determining factor and subsequently, androgen by male gonads.

choices.text: Absence of menses by age 15 yrs
No menses within 3 years of thelarche

questions.text: Which of these will not require evaluation for primary amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Primary amenorrhea is defined as:

  • Absence of menses by 15 years of age in presence of secondary sexual characters(breast budding +) (Option A)OR
  • Absence of menses by 13 years of age in absence of secondary sexual characters(breast budding -) (Option D)OR
  • No menses within 3 years of thelarche(Option B)

Option C doesn't come under the purview of primary amenorrhea

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association with HRT?
questions.solution:
Benefits of HRT:

  • Decreases vasomotor symptoms
  • Decreases colorectal cancer
  • Decrease risk of fracture(Option D)
  • Increase bone mineral density

Contraindication to HRT: mnemonic: ABCC

  • Active liver disease or gall bladder disease
  • Undiagnosed abnormal vaginal Bleeding
  • Known or suspected breast or endometrial Cancer(Option B,C)
  • CVD

questions.text: A 38-year-old multigravida presents with 2 years of infertility and dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea.On examination uterus is retroverted and there is tenderness in pouch of douglas. What would be next step of management?
questions.solution:
This patient is having endometriosis.

TRIAD OF ENDOMETRIOSIS: Infertility + dyspareunia + dysmenorrhea

  • First step to diagnosis is On TVS there is presence of chocolate cyst (ground glass appearance). It also helps to rule out other causes of dysmenorrhea
  • IOC: Diagnostic LAPAROSCOPY
  • GOLD standard: laparoscopy followed by histological examination of excised tissue
  • CA-125 levels are also raised

questions.text: A 32 years old G2A1 woman presents to casualty with complaints of abdominal pain at 20 weeks of gestation. She also gives history of fever and acute abdominal pain. On examination, BP: 120/80 mmHg and PR: 90bpm. On obstetric examination, fundal height corresponds to 28 weeks with mild tenderness, FHR: 130 bpm. Emergency USG was done and revealed single live intrauterine gestation with a fibroid on anterior wall of uterus. Blood profile shows WBC: 19000/mmcube and ESR raised. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is typical of red degeneration of fibroid.

Red degeneration of fibroid

  • Occurs in second half of pregnancy
  • Causes: Thrombus formation: Any hypercoagulable state like pregnancy, thrombosis is followed by necrosis

Clinical features:

  • Severe abdominal pain in mid trimester of pregnancy + pyrexia + leukocytosis + ESR is raised.
  • Self-limiting condition, caused by aseptic degeneration of fibroid
  • It subsides in 10-14 days
  • Treatment is conservative

Option A. Torsion of a fibroid occurs when a pedunculated fibroid, which is a fibroid attached to the uterus by a stalk or pedicle, twists on its own axis. This twisting cuts off the blood supply to the fibroid, leading to ischemia (lack of blood flow), necrosis (tissue death), and potentially severe pain.

Key points:

  1. Symptoms: Sudden, severe abdominal or pelvic pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, and signs of peritoneal irritation.
  2. Complications: If untreated, torsion of a fibroid can lead to infection, tissue death, and in rare cases, sepsis.
  3. Diagnosis: Typically confirmed through imaging techniques like ultrasound or MRI.
  4. Treatment: Requires surgical intervention, often via laparoscopy or laparotomy, to untwist or remove the fibroid. If there's tissue necrosis, the fibroid may need to be excised. In some cases, hysterectomy might be considered.

Option C,D: this doesn't seem like infection or malignancy

questions.text: All of the following can result in non-immune fetal hydrops except:
questions.solution:
Rh isoimmunization or ABO incompatibility are causes of Immune hydrops

  • The most common cause of hydrops fetalis: Non immune > immune
  • Most common cause of non immune hydrops: CVS anomalies
  • Most common cause in 2nd trimester: Aneuploidy
  • Most common infection: Parvovirus infection

Causes of non immune hydrops are as follows:

questions.text: Banana sign in pregnancy is characteristically seen in:
questions.solution:
Banana sign : Caudal displacement of cerebellum resembles a banana

Lemon sign: Head shape appears like a lemon due to scalloping of frontal bone

These features are associated with Neural tube defects like Spina bifida and Arnold Chiari malformation

C. Anencephaly shows a frog like appearance on USG.

questions.text: Which of the following is of least significance in the workup of turner mosaic?
questions.solution:
Antinuclear antibodies are useful to detect SLE which was not associated with turner syndrome.

Periodic medical evaluation is indicated in turner syndrome and should include the following:

  • Echocardiography (at diagnosis, at least once between the ages of 12 and 15

years, and every 5 years if normal; more often if abnormal)(Option A)

  • Renal ultrasonography (once if normal, every 3-5 years if abnormal)
  • TSH and free T4 (at diagnosis and every 1-2 years)
  • Complete blood count, fasting glucose, lipid profile, renal function tests, and

liver enzymes (every 2 years) and OGTT(Option D)

  • Antiendomysial antibodies, to detect celiac disease (at diagnosis) NOT ANA
  • Audiometry (at diagnosis, at least once during the teen years or young

adulthood, and every 10 years if normal)(Option B)

choices.text: Pain begins 1 day prior to the onset of menses and resolves in 48-72 hours
GnRH is the 1st line of treatment
It is dependent on psychological factor
Pain starts 2-3 days prior to menses and resolves in 24 hours

questions.text: Which of the following statement about primary dysmenorrhea is true?
questions.solution:
PRIMARY DYSMENORRHEA

  • Etiology: excessive or imbalanced amount of prostanoid secretion from the endometrium during menstruation
  • Increased uterine contraction with dysrhythmic pattern
  • Pain begins few hours before or just after onset of menstrual periods and may last for 48-72 hours.(Option A,D ruled out)
  • It is associated with psychological factors
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea
  • Management: NSAIDs are first line of drug.(Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A male presented with azoospermia, acidic semen with low fructose level. LH and FSH levels are normal. What can be the cause?
questions.solution:
Normal levels of FSH and LH suggests post testicular cause or obstructive azoospermia.

Following are the different types of azoospermia:

Causes of Obstructive azoospermia can be divided into:

  • Obstruction below the level of seminal vesicles: Either Block in Ejaculatory duct or Retrograde ejaculation.
  • Bilateral absence of seminal vesicles associated with absence of Vas(CBAVD) seen in Cystic fibrosis.

Both these causes can present with absence of fructose in semen.

Block above level of seminal vesicle: Semen is of good volume and fructose present

questions.text: A 15 year old female presents with primary amenorrhea and signs of virilization. She has prepubertal development of breasts and pubic hair and is tanner stage 2. She has a blind ended vagina and clitoromegaly. She has normal male testosterone levels. Her genotype is 46XY. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Steroid 5-alpha reductase deficiency

  • AR, 46 XY
  • Severe perineal hypospadias
  • Impaired virilization during embryogenesis
  • Defect in conversion of testosterone to DHT
  • PRESENTATION: failed fusion of labioscrotal fold, clitoromegaly, shoretened and blind vagina, virilization at the time of puberty, breast development is normal
  • Diagnosis: genital ambiguity in infants + characteristic phenotype in youg adults and adolescents + normal testosterone level and increased testosterone / DHT ratio

B. Swyer syndrome: Gonadal dysgenesis happens due to mutation in SRY gene in 46XY individuals leading to absence of AMH, leading to presence of female internal genitalia(uterus present)(hence ruled out)

C. Androgen sensitivity syndrome: Resistance to Testosterone leading to no pubic hair, very well developed breasts(hence ruled out)

D. MRKH syndrome is associated with 46XX and is due to failure of differentiation of mullerian duct leading to absent of Fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix and upper 2/3rd of vagina(Hence ruled out)

questions.text: A 32 year old woman visits the OPD with history of painless ulcer on vulva. Her obstetric history reveals a preterm birth at 28 weeks. She has got contacts with multiple sexual partners. Next step of management is?
questions.solution:
Painless ulcers on genitalia is suggestive of Syphilis.

Also Syphilis shows Kassowitz Law: In the subsequent births, the outcome of pregnancy improves i.e likelihood of infection in fetus in later pregnancies becomes lesser. In other words, in cases of syphilis, the greater the duration between the infection of the mother and conception, the better the outcome of the infant. Features of a better outcome include less chance of stillbirths and of developing congenital syphilis.

Hence IOC in Syphilis is VDRL.

questions.text: Choose the incorrectly matched pair:
questions.solution:
Anterior colporrhaphy is done for Cystocele whereas Colposuspension is for Stress urinary incontinence.

Following are the procedures for various conditions:

questions.text: In 46 XX female on doing amniocentesis complete gonadal dysgenesis was noted. Complete gonadal dysgenesis is caused by what in the SRY gene?
questions.solution:
Complete gonadal dysgenesis is also known as SWYER SYNDROME.

In this approximately 15-20% of patients, the disorder results from an inactivating mutation in SRY gene, but in most cases cause is not known.

(Deletion in SRY gene's DNA binding region 2 is present in 10-20 % of women)

questions.text: Which of the following is not prenatally transmitted?
questions.solution:
The TORCH acronym reflects the infections toxoplasmosis, others, rubella, and cytomegalovirus and herpesvirus infections.

These can cross the placenta to cause fetal infection and substantial neonatal sequelae.

SPECIFIC CAUSES OF SOME FETAL AND NEONATAL INFECTIONS:
